cmCourseInfo.description: Forest conservation issues in Canada; fundamentals of forest biology and ecology; forest biodiversity; development of forest management philosophy in Canadian forested regions; concepts of sustainability. Sustainable forest management strategies; forest policy and economics in a Canadian context; forest certification; protected areas.
cmCourseInfo.title: Conservation of Canada's Forests
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

courses.name: Conservation of Tropical and Subtropical Forests

cmCourseInfo.description: The world's major tropical and subtropical forest biomes; prospects for conservation and sustainable management; consequences of different forest development strategies; tropical deforestation and selective logging; agroforestry; biodiversity and non-timber forest products; the fuelwood crisis; large carnivore conservation; ecological, economic and social perspectives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Conservation of Tropical and Subtropical Forests
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmCourseInfo.description: Traditional and non-traditional forest products; wood structure; properties and material attributes; functional characteristics and logistics of wood product industry. Contribution of innovative product development to conservation; adding value; residue use; biorefinery; under-utilized species; wood protection. Forest product certification; eco-labelling; life cycle analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forest Products in Sustainable Forestry
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

department.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to the field methods used by forest conservationists in Ontario. This field course will last 10-days from August 30 September 8 approximately. Field exercises will provide students with practical training in tree identification, forest ecosystem classification, forest inventory, stand management prescriptions, tree marking, and silvicultural systems. Each student is required to pay an ancillary fee of approximately $650 to cover the costs of their transportation and accommodation. Students must contact the Faculty to register; we strongly recommend that you do so by the end of May, but later registrations will be considered if class size permits. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Field Methods in Forest Conservation
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The field camp portion of the course will be taking place Friday August 18 to Friday August 26, 2023. Priority enrollment is given to Forestry Specialist and Major students. Forestry program students will receive emails about course details prior to the enrollment start period. Administrative contact is Laura Lapchinski, Program Administrator, laura.lapchinski@daniels.utoronto.ca. Specialist students who require this course to meet program requirements but cannot attend the above dates should reach out to Laura Lapchinski.

Delivery Instructions

The field camp portion of the course will be taking place Friday August 18 to Friday August 26, 2023. Priority enrollment is given to Forestry Specialist and Major students. Forestry program students will receive emails about course details prior to the enrollment start period. Administrative contact is Laura Lapchinski, Program Administrator, laura.lapchinski@daniels.utoronto.ca. Specialist students who require this course to meet program requirements but cannot attend the above dates should reach out to Laura Lapchinski.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will provide diverse perspectives about societal values and forests, such as Indigenous perspective, ecosystem services and human well-being, climate change and carbon sequestration, and forest management systems, such as community-based forest management and adaptive management systems; and will develop an understanding of the need of integrative approach to address the social, cultural, economic, and scientific issues associated with forest management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Societal Values and Forest Management
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

department.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Global forest resources; relationships between societies and forests, consumption, trade and valuation of timber and non-timber products; ecosystem services, climate change and forestry, tropical deforestation and softwood lumber dispute.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Dimensions of Global Forests
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

department.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the biology of trees and the ecological principles that govern the structure and function of forests. Topics in tree biology will include tree identification, wood anatomy, tree architecture, resource acquisition and allocation, tree growth and mortality. Topics in forest ecology will include resource competition, stand development, species succession, and the cycling of nutrients and energy. This course will include a substantial field and lab component.
cmCourseInfo.title: Biology of Trees and Forests
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmCourseInfo.description: Insect identification and ecology, biodiversity and conservation, invasive species, insect-tree interaction, biological control, pesticide use, and integrated pest management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forest Insect Ecology & Management
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmCourseInfo.description: Socio-economic, technical, political and environmental issues associated with the utilization of forest biomass (e.g., harvesting residues, thinnings, salvage, short rotation woody crops) for a source of renewable energy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioenergy from Sustainable Forest Management
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Completion of at least 6.0 Science credits
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of current and emerging critical issues affecting sustainable management and conservation of global forests. Seminars led by students, faculty and visiting speakers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Seminar in Forest Conservation
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmCourseInfo.description: Individual in-depth student research projects on significant forest conservation and forest biomaterial issues, based on field and/or laboratory research, or literature survey. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Paper/Thesis in Forest Conservation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 15.0 credits including 1.0 credit from: FOR300H1/FOR301H1/FOR302H1/FOR303H1/FOR305H1/FOR306H1/FOR307H1/FOR310H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Technological advances and approaches in deriving biofuels and chemical feedstocks from forest and other biomass. Fundamental chemical attributes of biomass, as they affect the fuel value and potential for deriving liquid, solid and gaseous fuels and valuable chemicals for other applications will be discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Bioenergy and Biorefinery Technology
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Completion of at least 10.0 Science credits
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

department.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Temperate and tropical wildlife ecology and conservation; roles of wildlife in forest conservation; impacts of forestry practices and landscape modification on wildlife; ecology and viability of wildlife populations; human uses and abuses of game and non-game species.
cmCourseInfo.title: Wildlife Ecology & Conservation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FOR200H1, FOR201H1, EEB319H1, EEB321H1, EEB323H1, EEB324H1, ENV234H1 + Completion of 15.0 credits
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

department.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Trees in and around the city are key to providing multiple engineered and ecological services that only recently have been brought into the responsible fiscal planning of every municipality around the globe. Reviews the role of trees and woodlands in providing environmental, social and economic benefits to urban and peri-urban residents and to the broader environment. Examines approaches to the characterization of urban forest ecosystems, and their planning and management.
cmCourseInfo.title: Green Urban Infrastructure
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

department.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: The roles of trees and forests in agricultural land-use systems primarily in the third world. An examination of the biological and management aspects of agroforestry, within the socio-economic constraints of the developing world. The sustainability of particular agroforestry systems is a theme throughout.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ecological Principles of Agroforestry
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

Course will be offered online synchronous.

Delivery Instructions

Course will be offered online synchronous.

cmCourseInfo.description: Understanding forest fire activity is important for predicting fire's impact on forests and the wildland-urban interface, as well as understanding the impacts of climate change. Basic principles of forest fuel moisture exchange, fire occurrence and fire behaviour are explored. Emphasis is placed on application of these models to real fire management problems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Forest Fire Behaviour and Management
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One course in quantitative methods, linear algebra or calculus
publicationSections: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmPublicationSections.section: Forest Conservation and Forest Biomaterials Science

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on the manufacturing processes, properties and uses of wood and agricultural fibre based products including wood based composites, ligno-cellulosic/thermoplastic composites and structural or engineered composites, and the practical use of these products in design.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sustainable Materials Design and Manufacturing
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Completion of at least 10.0 Science credits
